Award.AwardTitle: QIP 2018 Student and Postdoctoral Fellow Travel Funding Support

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports students and postdoctoral scholars to attend the twenty-first Workshop on Quantum Information Processing (QIP 2018). QIP is a flagship international conference in theoretical quantum computation and information, and has a long history in the field. This year up to 500 participants are anticipated, continuing the tradition of having QIP act as the primary annual meeting point for theoretical quantum information researchers worldwide.

QIP 2018 will be hosted by QuTech at the Delft University of Technology (Aula Congress Centre), located in Delft, The Netherlands, on January 13-19, 2018. The funds will be used to provide 12-14 travel awards for U.S.-based students and postdoctoral researchers. The aim is to support young researchers who might not otherwise be able to attend QIP 2018 due to financial shortfalls. Particular attention will be given to students who are female or from underrepresented groups, and those with accepted papers at QIP 2018.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant gave financial travel assistance to 12 U.S.-based young researchers in attending the premier international conference on theoretical quantum computation, the 21st Workshop on Quantum Information Processing (QIP 2018). The study of quantum computation is a cutting-edge field bridging the fields of computer science, physics, and mathematics, and aims to develop the next paradigm of computing technology. The United States is one of the world's leaders in this international collaborative effort, and broadly speaking, this grant aims to keep U.S. researchers at the forefront of this field.

Specifically, the current grant allowed young researchers from across the United States to attend and present work at QIP 2018 in Delft, The Netherlands. This not only provided an excellent opportunity for training and learning, but also to network with top researchers from around the globe.

Twelve researchers from 8 U.S. universities received awards under this grant in order to help cover travel, lodging, and conference registration. The awards were distributed based on funding need, merit, and identification in underrepresented groups. Of the awardees, 6 presented a research talk, 3 presented a research poster, 1 was a postdoctoral researcher, 10 were graduate students, and 1 was an undergraduate student. Funds were disbursed so as to represent as broad a spectrum of U.S. institutions as possible.
